definition[0]: from a particular time or event in the past until the present, or in that period of time
example[0]: We’ve been waiting here since two o’clock.
example[1]: I haven’t played rugby since I left university.
example[2]: She left London ten years ago, and I haven’t seen her since.
example[3]: The factory has been here since the 1970s.
example[4]: It was exactly five years since her father had died.
example[5]: Since the end of the war, over five thousand prisoners have been released.
example[6]: He lost his job five years ago, but has since found other work.
example[7]: I left school in 1995, and since then I’ve lived in London.
example[8]: We’ve been friends ever since we were at school together.
example[9]: She’s been terrified of the sound of aircraft ever since the crash.
example[10]: We came to the UK in 1974 and have lived here ever since.
definition[1]: used to give the reason for something
example[11]: Since you are unable to answer, perhaps we should ask someone else.
explanation[0]: You use since with a time, year, date, or other point in time
example[12]: He has been living in England since 2008
example[13]: We’ve known about it since May
explanation[1]: Don’t use since with a period of time
bad_example[0]: He has been living in England since 12 years
explanation[2]: You use the present perfect before since
example[14]: I have liked him since we first met
example[15]: We’ve been driving since six this morning
bad_example[1]: I like him since we first met
explanation[3]: You also use the past perfect before since
example[16]: She had been waiting since five o’clock
bad_example[2]: She was waiting since five o’clock
explanation[4]: You use the simple past tense after since
example[17]: He has grown since I last saw him
explanation[5]: You use for with a period of time
example[18]: I’ve known him for ten years
